Support effect on the chemical properties of Mn2O3/Na2WO4/MOx catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane Jiaxin Song Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Software Formal analysis Data curation a b Xiaoqiang Fan Writing – original draft Validation Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ Baijun Liu Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization b Zhen Zhao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎⁎ a Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034, China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034. b State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249 ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang 110034, China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China The high stability and excellent performance of NaWMn based catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) are expected to promote their industrial application. However, the selection of supports has significant impact on the OCM performance of NaWMn-based catalysts. In this work, we found that the addition of Na2WO4/MOx to Mn2O3 can change the function of the Mn2O3 catalyst from methane combustion to oxidative coupling of methane, and the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst exhibits the highest performance. The isotope oxygen exchange and CH4-TPSR results confirm that the appropriate oxygen exchange rate is beneficial for improving the catalytic performance of OCM reaction. H2-TPR and O2-TPD results demonstrate that the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst has moderate redox ability and can slowly release oxygen species at lower temperatures, matching the rate of methane consumption with the rate of C2 generation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts Solid-phase grinding Intimate contact Oxygen exchange rates Oxidative coupling of methane Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane (CH4) is the main component of natural gas and is widely regarded as a promising alternative to crude oil resources. Compared with direct combustion of methane, the development of processes for converting CH4 into value-added chemicals has economic and environmental benefits, and the most noteworthy of such processes is the direct conversion of CH4 into C2 species through the oxidative coupling of methane [1–3]. Nevertheless, effective catalytic performance usually requires harsh reaction conditions (700 °C–800 °C), which facilitate the deep oxidation of C2 to COx compounds, resulting in an upper bound of catalyst of 25 %–28 % for C2 yield [4]. To improve the catalyst performance for OCM, highly efﬁcient catalysts have been designed and fabricated, including Na-W-Mn (NaWMn) oxides [5,6], rare earth oxides [7,8], ABO3 perovskite-type oxides [9,10], and Li-MgO [11,12]. Among these catalysts, the high stability and performance of NaWMn/SiO2 catalysts are of particular interest. In the OCM reaction, the most commonly used active components are Mn2O3 and Na2WO4, whereas the most extensively studied support materials are inert silica-based materials. Many researchers have attempted to improve the OCM performance of traditional NaWMn/SiO2 catalysts by replacing silica with other oxides or by doping foreign atoms to alter the properties of silica. Aireddy et al. evaluated Na-Mn-W oxide catalysts supported by titanate nanowires for the OCM, and found that the titanate support not only stabilizes the isolated MnOx species, but also serves as a reservoir for alkali metals. Moreover, this series of catalysts has a high selectivity for C2+ species, due to the strong interaction between NaOx/MnOx (alkaline) species and WOx/TiOx (acidic) species [13]. Sun et al. investigated the OCM catalytic performance of Mn2O3-Na2WO4 modified CexZr1-xO2 catalyst, showing that Mn2O3 and Na2WO4 act synergistically to induce Ce0.15Zr0.85O2 to produce more O2 −, resulting in better low-temperature activity and C2+ selectivity [14]. Recently, Fan et al. studied the OCM performance of LaCeZr ternary oxide-supported Mn-Na2WO4 catalyst. LaCeZr ternary oxide enhances the redox ability of the Mn-Na2WO4 catalyst, which is beneficial for activating O2 at lower reaction temperatures and generating more reactive oxygen species to activate CH4 and generate C2 species [15]. Yunarte et al. evaluated the Na2WO4 and Mn modified Mg-Ti-Si mixed oxides catalysts for OCM. Mg and Ti atoms enter α-cristobalite framework, leads to the enrichment of Na/W/Mn compounds on the catalyst, thereby improving the OCM performance [16]. Although in-depth research has been conducted on the impact of different supports on the performance of OCM, catalysts supported by inexpensive, inert SiO2 remain a hot topic of research owing to their high activity. Hayek et al. evaluated a series of β-zeo, SBA-15, and Fum-supported NaWMn/SiO2 catalysts for the OCM, and found that using zeolite as a support reduced the overall W concentration, thereby reducing the size of the Na2WO4 particles and linearly improving the performance of OCM [17]. Gu et al. prepared NaWMn/SiO2 catalysts using a layered zeolite D-ITQ-1 as a support. The characterization results indicate that tetrahedral WO4 units have better stability and dispersion on the delaminated zeolite with a thin, basal, all-silica nanosheet structure, thereby improving the OCM performance [18]. At present, NaWMn/SiO2 catalysts with a SiO2 support are usually prepared by impregnation [19], mixed slurry [20], urea-assisted hydrothermal [21], or sol–gel methods [16], although the confirmed role of SiO2 in the OCM is relatively simple, mainly the transformation of SiO2 into α-cristobalite, which is beneficial for enhancing the interaction between active components, and plays a role in stabilizing and dispersing the active phase. Previous studies have rarely investigated the effects of SiO2, TiO₂, La₂O₃, Al₂O₃, and MgO supports on the performance of OCM in the preparation of composite catalysts by solid-phase grinding. Therefore, utilizing the characteristics of the Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst and using a simple solid-phase grinding method to develop a functional conversion catalyst is of great significance for the study of new and efficient catalysts for the OCM. The properties of the support are the key factors affecting the enhancement obtained from mixing the two catalysts. For this study, Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts were prepared using a simple solid-phase synthesis method with different MOx (M=Si, Ti, La, Al, and Mg) supports. Various techniques, including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD), isotopic oxygen exchange, and CH4 temperature-programmed surface reaction (CH4-TPSR), to investigate the effects of different supports on the performance of OCM and to establish a comparison with SiO2, and to confirm that the catalyst supported on SiO2 yields the highest OCM performance in terms of potential in practical applications. It has been proven that catalysts loaded on SiO2 do achieve the best results in potential practical applications. The Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst exhibits the best performance, with a maximum yield of 18.5 % for C2 and 44.6 % conversion of CH4 at 800 °C. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalyst 2.1.1 Preparation of Na2WO4/MOx (NaWM) catalysts A series of Na2WO4/MOx catalysts was prepared using five different supports ( Table 1) in conjunction with the Na2WO4·2 H2O precursor (AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.). Using the Na2WO4/SiO2 (NaWSi) catalyst as an example, the amorphous SiO2 gel was impregnated with 0.11 g of Na2WO4·2 H2O and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The sample was dried at 80 ℃ and finally calcined at 800 °C for 4 h and then the Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst was obtained. The Mn2O3/NaWTi, Mn2O3/NaWAl, Mn2O3/NaWLa, and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts were prepared using the same procedures. 2.1.2 Preparation of Mn2O3 catalyst Mn2O3 was synthesized by glucose complexation; Mn(NO3)2 (3.58 g, 50 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) as the manganese source precursor and glucose (3.96 g, AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) as the complexant were dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the sample was stirred for 2 h (ambient temperature) to produce a homogeneous solution, and the solution was dried overnight, and calcined at 800 ℃ for 4 h. 2.1.3 Preparation of Mn2O3/Na2WO4/MOx (Mn2O3/NaWM) catalysts The Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts were prepared by a typical solid-phase grinding method. Briefly, Mn2O3 and NaWM with a mass ratio of 1: 2 were fully ground in an agate mortar for 30 min to obtain the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts. 2.2 Catalytic activity test The Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts were tested in the temperature range of 700 °C–800 °C, while maintaining the ﬂow rate constant at 25 mL/min (CH4:O2:N2 = 2:1:2). Analysis was performed using an online gas chromatograph (GC 2060) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, which used a DM Plot Msieve 5 A column for separating H2, O2, CO, and CH4. Additionally, a flame ionization detector with a DM Plot Q capillary column was used for CH4, C2H4, C2H6, CO2 and CO separation. The balance was always better than 95 %. CH4 conversion, C2 and COx selectivity, and C2 yield were deﬁned as follows: (1) A i = f r × C n × A i ′ (2) CH 4 conversion % = ∑ A i / ( ∑ A i + A C H 4 in outlet ) × 100 % (3) Selectivity i % = A i / ∑ A i × 100 % Calculate the yield of the product as follows: (4) Yield i % = ( Selectivity i ) × ( CH 4 conversion ) × 100 % Among them: A i represents the content of product i after calibration; A i ′ represents the peak areas corresponding to each product i obtained from the gas chromatography workstation; f r represents the relative correction factor based on methane; C n represents the number of carbon atoms contained in the reactant or product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity in the OCM 3.1.1 The effect of catalyst packing structure on performance in the OCM To study the effect of loading pattern on the OCM performance of composite catalysts, the activity of catalysts with different loading pattern was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 1. The NaWSi catalyst lacks surface-active oxygen species and has poor oxidation–reduction ability, as described in the literature [22,23], resulting in relatively low methane conversion. However, the conversion of methane on a single-component Mn2O3 catalyst is almost unaffected by temperature changes and remains between 25 % and 28 % within the reaction temperature range (Fig. 1A). Therefore, in this series of catalysts, Mn2O3 is mainly responsible for activating the C–H bond of CH4. Interestingly, adding the NaWSi catalyst in different loading patterns resulted in different improvements in methane conversion on the three composite catalysts compared with pure Mn2O3 catalysts at 750 °C, 800 °C, and 850 °C. However, the conversion of methane significantly increased on the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst prepared by physically mixing the Mn2O3 and NaWSi catalysts. The above experimental results suggest the importance of the contact interface between the Mn2O3 and NaWSi catalysts; the number of interfaces, to some extent, determines the synergy between the Mn2O3 and NaWSi catalysts. The catalytic enhancement of Mn2O3 and NaWSi in the dual-bed catalyst systems (Mn2O3-NaWSi and NaWSi-Mn2O3) is limited, and the large number of contact interfaces in uniformly mixed Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst may be the main reason for the further enhancement of methane conversion arising from the enhancement effect of mixing. The Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst achieved the highest methane conversion, except at 700 °C, with a maximum value of 44.8 % at 850 °C. Fig. 1A shows the relationship between the C2 yield and temperature for various catalysts. Within the reaction temperature range of 700 °C–850 °C, the C2 yield of all catalysts first tended to increase and then decrease as the temperature increased. The yield was greatest with Mn2O3/NaWSi, followed by NaWSi-Mn2O3 and then Mn2O3-NaWSi, with the C2 yield on the Mn2O3 catalyst was slim to none. The methane conversion and C2 yield on the catalyst prepared by solid-phase grinding method are relatively high, and the highest C2 yield of 18.5 % was achieved on the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst. Therefore, Mn2O3 and NaWSi catalysts exhibit a synergistic effect in enhancing methane activation and methyl radical desorption after solid-phase grinding. In Fig. 1B–D, the relationships between the selectivity of C2, CO, and CO2 are shown for various catalysts and temperatures. As the temperature increases, the selectivity of C2 on all catalysts first increases and then decreases. The Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst prepared by solid-phase grinding achieved optimal C2 selectivity at lower temperatures (T ≤ 800 °C), indicating that the introduction of Na2WO4/SiO2 by solid-phase grinding inhibited the deep oxidation of reactants and C2 to CO2, thereby improving the OCM performance of the catalyst. Compared with pure Mn2O3 catalyst, NaWSi-Mn2O3 and Mn2O3-NaWSi catalysts also exhibit higher C2 selectivity. This indicates that NaWSi and Mn2O3 also have a catalytic enhancement effect in the dual-bed catalyst, but the effects are not significant. This may be because the proximity distance between different active components is crucial for enhancing OCM activity. The enhanced catalytic effect of Mn2O3 /NaWM composite catalyst may be attributed to the close contact of different active centers, which regulates the subsequent reaction pathways of intermediates and effectively forms reaction coupling, improving methane conversion and C2 selectivity [24,25]. Another reason may be that Na2WO4 is in a molten state at the reaction temperature [26,27], causing it to migrate on the catalyst surface and interact with the Mn2O3 component. The interaction between the active components at the contact interface generates new and more active sites, thereby enhancing the catalytic effect. Therefore, a series of Mn2O3/Na2WO4/MOx composite catalysts was prepared by the solid-phase grinding of the Na2WO4/MOx and Mn2O3 catalysts, and their structure and activity were analyzed in subsequent studies. 3.1.2 The effect of different supports on the performance in the OCM The OCM reaction performance of Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts is shown in Fig. 2. Mn2O3/NaWLa catalysts exhibit high methane conversion but poor C2 selectivity, which is similar to the OCM performance of the Mn2O3/NaWAl catalyst. Fig. 2D and E also confirm that the Mn₂O₃/NaWLa and Mn₂O₃/NaWAl catalysts exhibit high selectivity for CO and CO₂ (particularly for CO₂ selectivity). The methane conversion of the Mn2O3/NaWTi and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts prepared with a transition metal oxide (TiO2) and an alkaline earth metal oxide (MgO) as supports is greatly affected by temperature, and the C2 selectivity has been greatly improved compared with the first two catalysts, which may indicate that the NaWTi and NaWMg catalysts have a strong synergistic effect with Mn2O3, showing a certain potential for catalytic development of OCM. Moreover, Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst prepared with a SiO2 as support resulted in greatly improved CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity. It is worth noting that the C2 yield has been significantly increased, showing the highest catalytic performance for OCM, indicating that SiO2 is an excellent support for these catalysts. It is possible that the presence of alkali metals can transform amorphous silica into the α-cristobalite phase because the α-cristobalite is beneficial for enhancing the interaction between active components and stabilizing the active phase [28–30], and Na2WO4 is unstable on Al2O3 and La2O3 supported catalysts may be one of the reasons for its poor activity. Furthermore, the H2-TPR characterization results confirm that the presence of NaWLa and NaWAl did not optimize the reducibility of pure Mn2O3 catalyst, suggesting that NaWLa and NaWAl did not have a regulatory effect on Mn2O3, and therefore could not exert the synergistic effect between active components. The Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst achieved 44.6 % conversion of CH4 and 18.5 % yield of C2 at 800℃. The stability of the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst in the OCM reaction is presented in Fig. 2D. No deactivation of the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst occurred after 24 h, the CH4 conversion remained at 44 %–45 % and the C2 yield remained at 18.5 %–18.8 %. Moreover, the comparisons of catalytic performance between the studied Mn₂O₃/NaWSi catalyst and the catalysts fabricated by other researchers were conducted (Table S2). The results indicate that, compared with these catalysts, the Mn₂O₃/NaWSi catalyst exhibits moderate activity for the formation of C₂ hydrocarbons from methane. 3.2 Structural characterization of Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts 3.2.1 XRD and N2 adsorption-desorption The XRD analysis of the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts and the phases detected over these catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 and Table 1, respectively. For all samples, the diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 crystal located at 33.3° could be detected [31], and no other manganese species were found [32], suggesting that there are no other manganese phases with large sizes (>3 nm) present on the catalyst surface. No characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to Na2WO4 were observed as shown in Fig. 1, indicating the uniform dispersity of Na2WO4 on the surfaces of the different supports. For the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst, the peaks at 22.1º and 36.1º assigned to α-cristobalite were also detected [33]. As previously shown, the amorphous phase presented in a SiO2 support can transform to the α-cristobalite phase after high-temperature calcination in the presence of Na, which is lower than the temperature for the phase change in the absence of Na [34]. Similarly, Dedov et al. also reported that the crystallization of SiO2 was crucial for the OCM and the selective catalytic formation of Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 [35]. For the Mn2O3/NaWTi catalyst, the anatase phase (25.3º, 48.1º, 53.9º) was dominant in the XRD patterns, and the weak diﬀraction peaks of rutile (27.5º, 36.1º, 54.3º) were also observed [36,37]. The XRD patterns of the Mn2O3/NaWLa catalysts show five dominant peaks located at 26.2º, 29.3º, 30.1º, 39.7º, 46.3º, and 52.34º, which relate to the (100), (002), (101), (102), and (103) of a typical La2O3 crystal [38]. However, no diffraction peak corresponding to Al2O3 was detected with the Mn2O3/NaWAl catalyst. Characteristic peaks belonging to the Mn2O3 and MgO were found in the XRD spectra of the Mn2O3/NaWMg catalyst [39]. The BET surface area and pore structure of the Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts with different supports are reported in Table 1. Compared with the pure support (as shown in Table 1), all composite catalysts have lower surface area, especially the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst. The specific surface area of the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst decreased from 200 to 14.3 m2 g−1 after impregnation and calcination. This could be explained by the presence of Na promoting the phase transition of amorphous SiO2 to cristobalite, causing a sharp decrease in surface area. The BET surface area and pore volume of the Mn2O3/NaWM composite catalysts with different supports are about 3–67 cm2 g−1 and 0.006–0.143 cm3 g−1, respectively. The above results suggest that there is no direct relationship between the surface area or pore volume of the catalyst and the OCM performance. 3.2.2 TEM and XPS The morphology of catalysts obtained by TEM/EDS mapping with different magnification are presented in Fig. 4. From the TEM image of all samples, the lattice structure was discerned to have spacings of 0.38 nm, which were attributed to the characteristic (211) planes of Mn2O3, which agreed with the XRD results. In addition, lattice stripes attributed to the support (TiO2, La2O3, MgO) were found on the Mn2O3/NaWTi, Mn2O3/NaWLa, and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts, respectively. EDS elemental mapping data provide more detailed information on the elemental dispersion of particles with different morphologies. The EDS spectra showed the presence of Mn, Na, W, M (Si/Ti/La/Al/Mg), and O in the sample. Interestingly, there is close contact between M-containing structures and Mn2O3. This means that particles belonging to different phases (compounds) have extended close contact. This result indicates a strong interaction between the active components (Mn2O3) and NaWM. Although the contact and distribution between the Mn2O3 and NaWM catalysts play an crucial role in the OCM performance, the above results indicate that both phases of the catalyst prepared by solid-phase grinding method are in close contact. In addition, the EDS analyses of Na and W in Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts supported on different supports reveal that the dispersion of Na and W is relatively high on all catalysts. However, there are still significant differences in the activity of catalysts with different supports, indicating that the properties of the support are factors affecting the performance of OCM. Moreover, XPS characterization (Table S1) confirmed that the surface of Mn2O3/NaWSi and Mn2O3/NaNTi catalysts had high concentrations of Na and W, indicating significant enrichment of Na and W in SiO2 and TiO2 supported catalysts, which is beneficial for improving the performance of OCM. 3.2.3 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is an efficient characterization for detecting the structure of a sample and can provide detailed information on the chemical structure and molecular interactions. The Raman spectra of the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts and NaWM are compared in Fig. 5. For the Mn2O3/NaWSi, Mn2O3/NaWAl, and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts, only the peaks of Mn2O3 can be detected at 190 and 316 cm−1, and no corresponding Raman signals appear for the support. In contrast, only obvious characteristic peaks attributed to the support were observed on the composite catalyst supported by TiO2 and La2O3. To determine the phase composition of the composite catalyst more clearly, the Raman spectra of the single-component NaWM were measured and is shown in Fig. 5B. The Raman spectrum of Mn2O3 (150–400 cm−1) is provided in Fig. 5B for reference. The Raman bands at 227 and 414 cm−1 can be assigned to α-cristobalite are apparent. Combining the results of Fig. 5B and literature results [40], the Raman bands at 629, 507, 389, 195, and 143 cm−1 in the NaWTi catalyst can be assigned as the Eg, A1 g, B1 g, Eg, and Eg modes of the anatase phase, respectively. However, no bands assigned to rutile (448 cm−1 and 610 cm−1) were observed. It is reported that the peaks at approximately 185 and 400 cm−1 attributed to the A1 g vibration mode of the lattice vibration of La-O in La2O3, and the bands at 306, 807, 923 cm−1 could be ascribed to MgO. For the Mn2O3/NaWAl catalyst [41,42], there is almost no Raman signal on the surface species of Al2O3 support below 1000 cm−1 [43], and the unknown attributed peaks at 953 and 857 cm−1 may be related to the fluorescence spectra of Al2O3 [44]. However, after mixing Mn2O3 with NaWSi, NaWAl, and NaWMg, the support peak with a weak Raman signal was covered by the signal from surface Mn2O3, whereas only the characteristic peak of the support was detected in the Mn2O3/NaWTi and Mn2O3/NaWLa catalysts, which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. This suggests that the physical and chemical properties exhibited by composite catalysts are greatly influenced by the support properties, which indicates the need to study the structure–activity relationship of composite catalysts with different supports. 3.2.4 H2-TPR H2-TPR was studied to investigate the redox features of the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts. In Fig. 6, it is shown that the reduction peaks of the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts are mainly ascribed to the reduction of Mn2O3, and the position of the reduction peak is highly dependent on the properties of NaWM. The reduction peaks of the pure Mn2O3 at 300 ºC–600 °C can be assigned to the reduction of Mn species, which was reported to occur in two steps: Mn2O3→Mn3O4→MnO [45]. The Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaWAl samples have similar reduction temperatures to Mn2O3, indicating that the interaction between NaWLa or NaWAl and Mn2O3 is weaker, making it easier to activate the C-H bond of CH4 and more inclined to deeply oxidize CH4 and C2 species to COx (Fig. 2), which may be one of the reasons for their similar activity to Mn2O3. However, the reduction temperature of Mn species on Mn2O3/NaWSi and Mn2O3/NaNTi catalysts shifted towards higher temperatures and significantly widened, indicating that reducing Mn2O3 in Mn2O3/NaWSi and Mn2O3/NaWTi catalysts is more difficult. This may be due to the strong interaction between Mn species and NaWSi, NaWTi, and moderate redox ability, which is more conducive to improving OCM activity, consistent with the activity evaluation results. 3.2.5 O2-TPD The oxygen species of the catalysts are considered as one of the signiﬁcant factors inﬂuencing the OCM reaction. O2-TPD studies were performed for Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts as shown in Fig. 7. It should be noted that pure Mn2O3 exhibits a strong oxygen desorption peak at 600–700 °C, while the oxygen desorption peak on the Mn₂O₃/NaWSi catalyst is broader and shows the lowest onset temperature among all the prepared catalysts (Fig. 7B). This indicates the Mn₂O₃/NaWSi catalyst can slowly release active oxygen in advance, matching the activation rate of methane with the formation rate of C2, thereby achieving higher C2 selectivity and CH4 conversion. The Mn₂O₃/NaWMg catalyst also has a lower O2 desorption peak temperature, making it easier to selectively produce C₂ products. The oxygen desorption peaks for the Mn2O3/NaWTi, Mn2O3/NaNLa, and Mn2O3/NaWAl catalysts are concentrated at 831 °C, 836 °C, and 849 °C, respectively, which are significantly higher than the temperature of the oxygen peak in pure Mn₂O₃. Furthermore, for the Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaNAl catalysts, the oxygen species are released within a narrow temperature window but in large quantities. The rapid desorption of a large amount of oxygen species in the high temperature leads to excessive oxidation of methane to produce COx. This may be the reason why the Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaNAl catalysts have high methane activation capabilities but poor C₂ selectivity. The above results confirm that the release of oxygen from the catalyst is directly related to the nature of the support in different catalysts. The slowly release of oxygen species from the catalyst at lower temperatures may be beneficial for improving its OCM performance. 3.2.6 CH4-TPSR Fig. 8 provides a more detailed description of the products formed by CH4-TPSR and further confirms the contribution of oxygen species in the OCM reaction for the different supports. The formation of CO2 can only be observed on Mn2O3, Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaWAl catalysts below 650 ºC. It is worth noting that the CO2 released of Mn2O3/NaWLa catalyst observed in Fig. 8 is unlikely to be solely due to residual La₂(CO3)3, as the Raman spectroscopic characterization of Mn2O3/NaWLa does not show a clear La₂(CO3)3 characteristic peak at 1100 cm−1. As the temperature increases, the CO signal increases sharply, and there is no selective generation of C2H6 and C2H4 signals across the entire temperature range over Mn2O3, Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaWAl catalysts. This suggests that the oxygen species over these samples cannot selectively activate the C–H bond of CH4 and are responsible for the generation of deep oxidation products. The possible reason is that the addition of NaWLa and NaWAl did not weaken the reducibility of pure Mn2O3 catalyst. And there is no strong interaction between NaWLa, NaWAl and Mn2O3, the properties of oxygen species on Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaWAl catalysts is similar to Mn2O3, resulting in the similar OCM activities over these three catalysts. Moreover, the excessively high oxygen exchange rate observed in Mn2O3/NaWLa sample may lead to lattice oxygen migration and promoting complete oxidation of methane. Additionally, Na2WO4 is unstable on La2O3 and Al2O3 supported catalysts, which prevents the effective synergistic interaction between Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 phases. This may be one of the reasons for the higher content of CO and CO2 on Mn2O3/NaWLa and Mn2O3/NaWAl catalysts. Interestingly, under the same experimental conditions (lack of gas-phase oxygen), for the Mn2O3/NaWSi, Mn2O3/NaWTi, and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts, it can be observed that C2H6 formation starts at 675 ºC, followed by the almost simultaneous production of C2H4 and CO. As the temperature increases, the content of selective products (C2H6 and C2H4) on the catalyst significantly increases, and the CO and CO2 signals increase slowly. It can be inferred that the presence of selective reactive oxygen species in the Mn2O3/NaWSi, Mn2O3/NaWTi, and Mn2O3/NaWMg catalysts facilitates the selective cleavage of methane C–H bond to inhibit advanced oxidation. Furthermore, stronger ethylene and ethane signals were observed with the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst. Therefore, higher C2 selectivity was also obtained with the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst (Fig. 2B). Combined with the H2-TPR and O2-TPD characterization, the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst has moderate oxidation–reduction ability and can slowly release surface-active oxygen species with a low release temperature, which is beneficial for the selective activation of CH4 by surface oxygen species. This may be the main reason that the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst has the best OCM activity. 3.2.7 Oxygen isotopic exchange To further investigate the effect of oxygen species migration on the OCM reaction, isothermal oxygen isotope exchange tests were conducted on Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts, as shown in Fig. 9A. During the process of oxygen isotope exchange, three reactions may occur, as shown in Fig. 9B [46,47]. When analyzing the time at which the different oxygen species appeared, it was found that 16O2 was formed at the beginning of the reaction, and the desorption effect of 16O2 was more significant than that of 16O18O for all catalysts. These results confirm the occurrence of a third type of exchange reaction (Eq. (3)) on the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts at the beginning of the exchange, indicating that the oxygen exchange reaction may consist mainly of multiple multiphase oxygen exchange reactions. In the initial stage of isothermal IOE testing, the low concentration of 18O2 in the gas phase is consumed as it is being exchanged for 16O2 and 16O18O. As the reaction time increases, the amount of 16O that can be exchanged on the catalyst is lower, and the concentration of 16O2 decreases significantly. However, the exchange reaction of the generated 16O18O is still progressing slowly, while the concentration of 18O2 increases and remains in equilibrium. The suggestion is that simple multiphase reactions gradually start to dominate as the reaction time increases. Many researchers have confirmed through isothermal isotope exchange tests that when oxygen species is used as an active substance in a reaction, a higher oxygen exchange capacity of the catalyst corresponds to a higher catalytic activity [48,49]. It is interesting that Mn2O3/NaWSi catalysts with high OCM performance only exhibit moderate oxygen exchange rate, while Mn2O3/NaWLa catalysts with poor OCM activity exhibit significantly higher oxygen exchange rate than other catalysts within the exchange time. This is consistent with the characterization results of O2-TPD and CH4-TPSR. Based on the analysis of activity evaluation results (Fig. 2), catalysts with strong oxygen exchange rate are more likely to lead to deep oxidation of the reaction, while moderate oxygen exchange rate is beneficial for improving the catalyst performance of OCM reaction. The Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst did not exhibit stronger migration rate of active oxygen species, which may be due to the strong interaction between NaWSi and Mn2O3, indicating that the chemical properties of the support are a key factor affecting the OCM performance of this series of catalysts. 4 Conclusion Extensive research has been conducted to determine the NaWMn/SiO2 catalyst with the best comprehensive performance. Previous research found that the three active components, Mn2O3, Na2WO4, and α-cristobalite were interdependent, and their synergistic effect is an important factor in achieving the optimal OCM activity. In this work, the Mn2O3/NaWM catalysts was prepared using a simple solid-phase grinding method. XRD and Raman spectroscopic characterization confirmed the phase composition of the catalyst. Intimate contact between Mn2O3 and NaWM phases was observed from the TEM images, suggesting that close contact is not the reason for the interaction between the two phases. Subsequently, the characterization of H2-TPR, O2-TPD, IOE, and CH4-TPSR demonstrated that the support of catalyst is the key factor determining the performance of OCM. Catalysts with high oxygen exchange rates are more likely to lead to deep oxidation of the reaction, while moderate oxygen exchange rates are beneficial for improving the catalytic performance of OCM reactions. The catalyst loaded on SiO2 can selectively activate methane, which is beneficial for the production of C2 and avoids excessive oxidation of reactants and target products. In this study, by examining the physicochemical properties of composite and single catalysts, the structure-activity relationships of the catalysts has been thoroughly analyzed. It not only explores oxide supports of research value (TiO₂ and MgO) for future studies but also provides a new approach for preparing highly efficient composite catalysts for OCM reactions. coredata.dc:description: The high stability and excellent performance of NaWMn based catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) are expected to promote their industrial application. However, the selection of supports has significant impact on the OCM performance of NaWMn-based catalysts. In this work, we found that the addition of Na2WO4/MOx to Mn2O3 can change the function of the Mn2O3 catalyst from methane combustion to oxidative coupling of methane, and the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst exhibits the highest performance. The isotope oxygen exchange and CH4-TPSR results confirm that the appropriate oxygen exchange rate is beneficial for improving the catalytic performance of OCM reaction. H2-TPR and O2-TPD results demonstrate that the Mn2O3/NaWSi catalyst has moderate redox ability and can slowly release oxygen species at lower temperatures, matching the rate of methane consumption with the rate of C2 generation.
